answers.answer: I might could help with some of this.  Remember, your doctor is the best one to help guide you in reading lab results.The AST can be high w/ liver disease, skeletal muscle diseases (myositis and mulcular dystrophy), trauma, pancreatitis, renal infarct, eclampsia, cancer, cerebral damage, seizures, alcohol, heart tissue disease (heart attacks, pericarditis), and infections in the bloodstream.  Medicines: intramuscular injections, corticosteroids, primidone, antibiotics.I have had an elevated AST from time to time, but then it will go back to normal.  I'm pretty sure they look at the overall picture.  For example, if one thing is high, usually another test would coincide with that one to arrive at the dx.Creatinine - (low) Rule out liver disease, hepatic venous shunts, anorexia and pregnancy.Potassium (high) - Rule out Addison's disease (adrenal cortical insufficiency), dehydration, cardiac arrhythmia, severe renal disease, diabetes, hypoadrenalism, and hereditary hyperkalemia.CO2 (low) - rule out decreased ventilation, increased acidity from uncontrolled diabetes, kidney disease, heart shunts, and metabolic disorders.Hope this helps,God bless, Kara

question: My son's blood work just came back and it shows that he has high AST (52), low CO2 (21), low Creatinine (.26) and high Potassium (5.5), what does this mean??
title: What do my son's blood tests mean?
